entry.content:

entry.title: How to configure TCS on sales with a 27C certificate for a customer?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am looking for a solution like an indicator (Maintained ID) is triggered automatically once the PAN number is maintained in the Business Partner (BP).

The scenario for which solution is am looking for is involves configuring TCS on sales with a 27C certificate for a customer. Currently, this is achieved by adding the Sold-To party in the TCS access sequence.

Is there any standard solution or functionality where we can upload the certificate with a valid date range, so that the system sets the indicator for that range and resets it when the certificate is range expire?

This approach would eliminate the dependency on maintaining the Sold-To in the access sequence and allow a single record with a control codes to work effectively.

Your insights, experiences, or references to SAP Notes/Guidelines would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: How to Use Vendor Sub-Ranges in SAP MM for Multi-Currency Procurement
entry.content:
Hi @AK121, 

Thank you for your feedback and for sharing your experience.

In standard SAP, the currency in a Purchase Info Record (PIR) is derived from the vendor currency maintained in the BP master and does not automatically change based on the Vendor Subrange selected. The Vendor Subrange currency is designed to be applied during Purchase Order creation, not at PIR level. However, you can maintain the required currency manually while creating the PIR.

Thanks,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Re: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Hello 

While I would encourage anyone to write blogs at the same time I would request that they also think it through. What exactly does this script achieve here?

You havent shown the end to end process , all it does is read the SAP_ApplicationID which will never have the request count. Even If I believe for a minute that you took this header as a reference I haven't seen a single system sending the request count in a header to the middleware. What exactly is a request count?

You need to find the request count during runtime by checking how many messages have been processed for this integration or are under processing in last 5 minutes via the MPL odata api, but even that wont show 404, 4xx status codes which should be considered for such throttling.

This is not just impractical even if you had the request count but hasn't been thought through at all. If you are writing blogs please try to add some value.

Regards

vinay

entry.title: Re: Stop Treating SAP Patches Like Punishments - it's a gift
entry.content:
The mindset is important.

It's like having a car, everybody knows that the car must be controlled to avoid accidents, otherwise the accident will happen (Murphy law) and may kill. People must act as responsible citizens.

If someone tells us that there's a software security issue, of course it must not be seen as a problem, the processes must be adapted to live it as a normal situation. We professionals must act as professionals.

That's a problem everywhere (Nuclear power plants too!)

Although I advocate a lot, my colleagues (and sometimes clients) see the automated tests as optional. Everytime I develop a program, I use ABAP Unit. They don't. It's a mindset.

entry.title: Re: How to Convert Thunderbird Files?
entry.content: You can upload Thunderbird backup to Outlook by first converting Thunderbird MBOX files into PST format. Using a reliable MBOX to PST converter makes this process quick and ensures all emails and folders are preserved.

entry.title: Re: How to configure strictly "monitoring-only" access for specific SAP CPI integration fl
entry.content:
Maybe I was not clear enough, sorry for that...


if you do not cover package/iflow etc by AccessPolicy then those objects are accessible by default, by everyone that has PI_Business_Expert role collection.

So you have 2 options:
1. create access policies and assign all objects which should be secured from accessing -> assign those to respective role/role collection/user groups/users. All others not covered by Access policies are accessible

2 (I think this you are looking for ?) create generic access policy that will cover all iflows by adding rule: Integration Flow 'ID' matches '.*' -> then by default all iflows are not accessible. Only those that are part of specific Access Policies and assigned to users, are accessible
Here - you can also assign this "generic super access policy" to Super Users, then they have access to all

Extra tip üôÇ you can also assign role: AccessAllAccessPoliciesArtifacts to Super Users -> then they have access to all objects covered by AccessPolicies. This approach is helpful in option 1.

Hopefully, now this is explained clear enough and you find solution in it

br

Mateusz

entry.title: How to prevent BW/4HANA process chains from running when EDP pipeline fails?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have an external data processing (EDP) pipeline that feeds data into BW/4HANA. Currently, BW process chains run on a schedule, but we need to ensure that if the EDP pipeline fails, BW loads do not start.

What is the best approach to implement this dependency?

  • Should we use a control table or event-based triggering?
  • How can EDP communicate its success/failure status to BW/4HANA?
  • Any recommended best practices or SAP-supported patterns for this scenario?

Our goal is to avoid partial or incorrect loads in BW when upstream data is incomplete.

Thanks in advance for your guidance!

SAP BW/4HANA #EDP

entry.title: Migration cockpit- AA upload function
entry.content:
We are currently experiencing issues with the Migration Cockpit related to asset uploads, as outlined below:

  1. Fixed Asset Posting ‚Äì Unplanned Depreciation
    In the upload template for Fixed Asset Posting, there is no field available for unplanned depreciation. Could you please advise whether there is an updated template or an alternative function that supports mass upload of unplanned depreciation postings?

  2. Fixed Asset Master Data ‚Äì Time-Based Valuation
    In the upload template for Fixed Asset Master Data ‚Üí Time-Based Valuation, we are able to flag the Asset Shutdown indicator. However, we cannot find any column that allows us to input the date interval. We currently need to upload assets with more than one interval period. Could you please advise how this can be achieved using the Migration Cockpit?

Your guidance on the above would be greatly appreciated.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Migration cockpit- AA upload function
entry.content:
The issue mentioned can be solved by the below ways:

Firstly, for the Migration Object "Fixed asset - Postings", you can use the field "Subledger-Specific Line Item Type" to define the Cumulative Unplanned Depreciation using the SLALITTYPE as "07007".

Please refer to the below documentation regarding the same,

Fixed asset - Postings | SAP Help Portal

The other workaround solution is you can use the app "Upload Asset Details"

Upload Asset Details | SAP Help Portal

Secondly, for the Migration Object "Fixed asset - Master data", it is possible to maintain the date interval using the field "Planned Useful Life in Years" in the Sheet "Time-Based Valuation".

For Example,

Suppose you have an asset with the following intervals:

  • Interval 1: January 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020, with a depreciation key of "STRAIGHT_LINE" and a useful life of 5 years.
  • Interval 2: January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2021, with a depreciation key of "DOUBLE_DECLINING" and a useful life of 3 years

In the above case you can use the fields "Planned Useful Life in Years" and "Planned Useful Life in Periods" for defining the intervals for the specific amount of time the asset was used.

Fixed asset - Master data | SAP Help Portal

Thanks and Regards,

SAP Support.

Thanks in advance for your help! Happy holidays.

entry.title: SAP EWM RF Exception Handling - Deep Dive with BIDP- Partial Pick denial example
entry.content:
Business Scenario:

Let's set a quick business scenario, we have an outbound delivery order for a customer , where we need to pick 8 EA of the product from the warehouse. Say, we have Bin A and Bin B which have the stock for the product we are trying to pick.  The warehouse task is created to pick everything from Bin A, but while picking the picker using RF, encountered issue like only 2 EA are ok and rest are damaged, therefore, the picker will enter the exception code in EWM RF - e.g. BIDP ( Partial Pick denial) and system will then search  an alternate bin to pick the remaining 6 EA.

Example figure:

Source: Ai Generated


Note:   We can block  the Source Bin A also with the exception  handling  configuration  settings  with standard workflow  to  avoid picking the damaged stock or creation of WT's for any new orders. But this is not the scope of this blog.

RF Execution and Debugging:

1. We have an open WO to be picked, we use  'Selection  by WO' or 'selection by queue' or system guided  options

Created the  Pick HU and click F4 Next

2. Operator entered BIDP exception


Then operator hit Enter,

3. This will go the below perform  bind_check_and_initiate under FM- /SCWM/RF_PICK_EXCEPTION

It updates the BIND field which is the key parameter to  go for bin  denial 

In case of IV_IPRCODE = BIDP  which is  the  entered exception  code, it updates the BIND field in CS_ORDIM_CONFIRM-BIND

It then modify the ct_ordim_confirm

4. The control goes back to the DIFFBD function code. Which brings new screen to enter the actual quantity and the difference. then operator presses F1 Save.

The actual picking quantity is updated with 2 EA

Scan and confirm the Warehouse task.

Note:

I have used skip verification field  exception to skip scanning the source HU field . Therefore you may see **** in exception field in WT.

5. It goes to the class- /SCWM/CL_RF_CONFIRM_PICKING method CONFIRM where it calls the CREATE_BIN_DENIAL method.

This is the main class.

Here it tries to create new WT for the remaining quantity which is 6EA in this example, 

You can notice it will only pass the  IF statement  if the IS_ORDIM_CONFIRM-BIND not  initial, which is coming from above step 2.

Note:  The bin denial  scenarios is only considered for the below document categories.

6. Trying to find the source bin excluding the current bin with the remaining required quantity via FM  /SCWM/REM_BIN_DET

BAPIRET messages - Here we can see it found an alternate bin to pick the remaining quantity.

 

7. Then the information is passed to another FM /SCWM/TO_PREP_WHR_UI_INT to create the WT against the WHR

Important comment :

It tries to add into same Warehouse order by running simulations.

8. It returns to the picking screen again to  pick the remaining quantity within the same WO.

WT  status, bin to resource is confirmed

a. WT 9007928 is the original product WT with original pick quantity as 8 EA ( 2 EA actual pick + 6 EA Difference). Updated  with the below exceptions.

b. WT 9007932 is the new bin denial task to pick remaining 6 EA from different bin. Continue to  pick from this, note I have used SKFD in the new WT also.

Finally the  destination screen is shown-

Final WO status - confirmed.

END.

This concludes the blog. To sum up, we have seen  some insights with debug mode how the backend logic of BIDP exception works with the important class, method and function modules.

Thanks for reading. Please like and share your valuable comments.

 

Best Regards,

Y K B B Rudra Narayan

entry.title: Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog introduces the major position change-relevant posting journals, position flows (include derived business transactions) and position components‚Äô value change logic, over the full life of an interest-rate instrument, using an illustrative example created in the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

Illustrative Example

Data Preparation

Prepare the exchange rates between USD/EUR and EUR/USD.

Create an interest rate instrument (transaction type 100 - investment) and settle it.

‚ÄúStructure‚Äù of this transaction:

This transaction uses transaction currency USD. The nominal amount is 1,000,000.00 USD, the payment amount (for the initial principal increase flow) is 998,000.00 USD, so there is discount 2,000.00 USD. This transaction uses installment repayment for repayment structure.

An outgoing payment flow for charge (capitalized) is added in ‚ÄúOther Flows‚Äù. This flow is settled in EUR (‚â† transaction currency USD).

Check position indicator. The position currency (PC) is USD (=transaction currency), and the valuation currency (VC) is EUR (=local currency of the company code).

The example will focus on valuation area 002 (IFRS). 002 uses a position management procedure (PMP) 1IAS for this transaction, this PMP is designed for the measurement of the investment in debt instrument which is classified as ‚ÄúFair Value thru. Other Comprehensive Income (FVOCI)‚Äù. This PMP contains three valuation steps: amortization, security (M2M) valuation, FX valuation.

Check ‚ÄúCash Flow‚Äù:

 

Initial Recognition and Measurement

Run Fix, Pay and Post Flows (app ID: TBB1) on 24.10.2025.

Posting log:

  • MM1100-: principal increase amount in PC is 998,000.00 USD, its amount in VC = 998,000.00* 0.8543 = 852,591.40 EUR. 0.8543 is the exchange rate on 24.10.2025.
  • MM1902-: the payment currency of flow 1902 is EUR, its credit side is posted in bank clearing account with the transaction currency (TC, =PC) EUR, but its debit side recognizes position which must be posted in position currency USD, therefore, the clearing account is involved in the journal entries of MM1902- and it has the identical amounts in VC within two journal entries.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check the position values in app Treasury Position Values -Classic (app ID: TPM12).

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

In this example, at initial recognition, only the position component purchase value is updated, and it is equal to the book value of this transaction. The purchase value is sourced from position flows with update types MM1100- and MM1902- on 24.10.2025. To verify which position component has been updated, you may check the Position Change Category in the app Treasury Position Flows - Classic (app ID: TPM13).

In addition, on 24.10.2025, the unamortized discount = nominal 1,000,000.00 - Amortized Acquisition Value 998,117.05 = 1,882.95 USD. It can also be expressed in the following manner: (1,000,000.00 - 998,000.00) - 117.05 = 1,882.95 USD.

In this example, the unamortized discount is not a standalone position component and not reflected in a standalone G/L account. This example‚Äôs amortization procedure uses the net method; if the gross method is used in amortization procedure, then the unamortized discount can be posted in the standalone discount account, and the position account will reflect the nominal 1,000,000.00 USD.

 

Subsequent Measurement

Month end closing

This transaction is classified as FVOCI, enter the NPV (fair value) 999,000.00 USD for 31.10.2025.

Execute valuation via app Run Valuation (app ID: TPM1).

The valuation log contains three steps:

The amortization log can be checked from TPM1:

This amortization procedure uses the effective interest rate (EIR) method, EIR was calculated during initial recognition.

Posting log for TPM1:

  • V300: the amount in PC is 286.34 USD, the details can be found from the amortization log. Its amount in VC = 286.34*0.8543 = 244.62 EUR, the exchange rate 0.8543 is the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) which was applied to the previous position change when initial recognition. With the position change effect of V300, the amortized acquisition value (AAV) in PC = 998,117.05 + 286.34 = 998,403.39, the AAV in VC = 852,691.40 +  244.62 = 852,936.02 EUR.
  • V200_OCI: the amount in PC = 999,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 596.61USD, the amount in VC = 596.61 * 0.8543 = 509.68 EUR, here the old exchange rate (on 24.10.2025) is applied. With the position change effect of V300, the position value in PC = 998,403.39 + 596.61 = 999,000.00 USD (= the fair value in USD), and the position value in VC = 852,936.02 + 509.68 = 853,445.70 EUR.
  • V203: 999,000.00*0.8512=850,348.80 EUR, this is the book value applied with the latest exchange rate on 31.10.2025; 850,348.80 - 853,445.70 = -3,096.90 EUR, 3,096.90 EUR is the unrealized FX valuation loss recognized during valuation run.

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

The unamortized discount = 1,000,000.00 - 998,403.39 = 1,882.95 - 286.34 =1,596.61 USD.

Installment repayment (24.11.2025)

Run TBB1 on 24.11.2025, the first installment repayment (500,000.00 USD) occurs at this date.

Positing log:

(These 4 update types are not relevant to posting, they are only fixed)

  • MM1130+: this position flow (500,000.00 USD in PC) recognizes the principal decrease directly arising from installment repayment, its amount in VC = 500,000.00* 0.8548 = 427,400.00 EUR; 0.8548 is the latest exchange rate for 24.11.2025.
  • DBT_C002: this is the derived business transaction for amortization, it is created automatically along with the original business transaction (MM1130+). For the details regarding how it is calculated, you may access TPM13, select the position flow DBT_C002, and click the button ‚ÄúAmort. Simulation‚Äù to check the detailed amortization log. Here, its amount in PC is 982.34 USD, its amount in VC = 982.34*0.8512=836.17 EUR; 0.8512 is the old exchange rate on 31.10.2025.

Check TPM13:

Amortization log (for DBT_C002):

Let‚Äôs now recap‚Äîbefore considering the effect of repayment flow‚Äîwhich position components make up the transaction‚Äôs book value, including the impact of DBT_C002.

Book value = purchase value + amortization + security valuation + FX valuation = 999,982.34 USD (851,184.97 EUR).

Upon repayment, the proportion of the nominal amount repaid to the original nominal determines how much of the position should be derecognized along with repayment. In this example, nominal decrease because of repayment 500,000.00 USD / total original nominal 1,000,000.00 USD = 50%; therefore, 50% of the book value (position) should be derecognized, the to be derecognized book value = 499,991.17 USD (425,592.49 EUR).

Now, let‚Äôs have a look at how and why the following four position flows are calculated (they are not relevant to posting, no posting journals are generated directly from them).

  • DBT_E001: till now, the amount in PC of position component purchase value is 998,117.05 USD; 998,117.05*50%=499,058.53 USD. The amount in VC of position component purchase value is 852,691.40 EUR; 852,691.40*50%=426,345.70 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E001 carries the amounts of proportionate purchase value which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E003: till now, the amount in PC of position component securities valuation is 596.61 USD; 596.61*50%=298.30 USD. The amount in VC of position component securities valuation is 509.68 EUR; 509.68*50%=254.84 EUR. The position flow of DBT_E003 carries the amounts of proportionate securities valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E006: till now, the amount in VC of position component FX valuation is -3,096.90 EUR; -3,096.90 *50%=-1548.45EUR. DBT_E006 carries the amounts of proportionate FX valuation which should be derecognized upon repayment.
  • DBT_E017: till now, the amount in PC of position component amortization is 1,268.68 USD; 1,268.68*50%=634.34 USD. The amount in VC of position component amortization is 1,080.79 EUR; 1,080.79*50%=540.40 EUR. DBT_E017 carries the amounts of proportionate amortization which should be derecognized upon repayment.

Calculate the book values to be derecognized again by summing the amounts of these position flows of DBT_E*:

  • The book value in PC to be derecognized = 499,058.53+298.30+634.34=499,991.17 USD.
  • The book value in VC to be derecognized = 426,345.70+254.84-1548.45+540.40=425,592.49 EUR.

Viewed differently, the DBT_E* position flows break down the book value that will be derecognized into its individual position component pieces.

MM1130+ derecognizes the investment position 500,000.00 USD (PC) and 427,400.00 EUR (VC), they are the real incoming payment amounts because of repayment. However, there are differences between MM1130+ and above calculated book values in PC and VC to be derecognized, therefore, position flows of DBT_B002 and DBT_B006 are generated to handle the differences:

  • DBT_B002: 500,000.00-499,991.17=8.83 USD; 8.83*0.8512=7.52 EUR, here the old exchange rate 0.8512 is applied. DBT_B002 is the realized price gain because derecognized book value in PC is less than the received repayment amount in PC.
  • DBT_B006: 427,400.00-425,592.49-7.52=1799.99 EUR. DBT_B006 is the realized FX gain because the derecognized book value in VC is less than the received repayment amount in VC.

The combination of MM1300+, DBT_B002, and DBT_B006 causes exactly 499,991.17 USD and 425,592.49 EUR are derecognized upon repayment from accounting perspective. Till now, the position account-relevant journals and balance in T-accounts are as follows:

Check TPM12:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

Previously we have explained DBT_E003, it carries the security valuation component to be derecognized: 298.30 USD (PC) and 254.84 EUR (VC). Consequently, the proportionate fair value change that was earlier recognized in OCI shall be reclassified to P&L because of partial derecognition of position; from an accounting perspective, DBS_E025 performs this reclassification adjustment posting, it carries the same amounts (in PC and VC) as DBT_E003.

Till now, the unamortized discount = 500,000.00 - 499,692.86 = 307.14 USD. You will see this unamortized discount will be amortized via the position flow of DBT_C002 on 24.12.2025 in the next section.

 

Derecognition

Final Repayment (last installment repayment, 24.12.2025)

Rune TBB1 on 24.12.2025. Posting log:

Show the position account-relevant journals in T-accounts:

Check TPM13:

Show the position component and position value calculation logic in the following manner.

No detailed walk-through of the complete derecognition-related position flows and postings is provided here, as the mechanics mirror those already described for subsequent measurement. In short, complete derecognition reduces the position value to zero.

 

Configuration

In this illustrative example, the position flows for Derived Business Transactions (update type DBT_*) are already generated and fixed and posted (if posting relevant) when the original business transaction leads to position change, this is because that in the configuration activity 104456 ‚ÄúControl Processing of Derived Business Transactions‚Äù, the field ‚ÄúOn/Offline‚Äù is specified as ‚ÄúOnline‚Äù, and ‚ÄúStatus Control‚Äù is specified as ‚ÄúSame Status‚Äù.

Field ‚ÄúOnline/Offline‚Äù:

  • Online: if you select ‚Äúonline‚Äù, then the derived business transactions are updated immediately every time an original business transaction leads to a change in a position. This setting is the predefined setting in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Offline: if you select ‚ÄúOffline‚Äù, then the derived business transactions are not generated immediately. To generate derived business transactions, you can sue the app Update Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM27).

Field ‚ÄúStatus Control‚Äù:

  • Same Status: the Derived business transactions always have the same status as the original business transaction.
  • Status Plan: the Derived business transactions are always generated with Plan (scheduled) status. You can use the app Post Derived Business Transactions (app ID: TPM18) to fix and post derived business transactions. Note: Some functions (such as the key date valuation) require that derived business transactions no longer have the status Plan.

 

Help Document

Please check help document Position Components for more details regarding position components.

entry.title: Re: How to configure TCS on sales with a 27C certificate...
entry.content: No functionality to upload a 27C certificate with validity dates that auto‚Äësets/resets indicators. Extend BP with certificate validity fields + implement BADI logic to toggle indicator + adjust condition table. This approach removes dependency on Sold‚ÄëTo in the access sequence and allows a single record with control codes to work effectively.

entry.title: Re: SAP ECC static credit limit not met, new order exceed...
entry.content: The system performs the credit check at save, not during entry.  Also, during save, system will trigger a message which can either be a warning message or an error message based on the configuration and Business decision.

entry.title: Re: How to store VA05 sales order list data into a custom...
entry.content:
Best practice is read from the underlying transparent tables (VBAK, VBAP, VBEP, VBKD, VBUK, VBUP). These are the authoritative sources for sales order data. SAP provides LIS (Logistics Information System) and BW extractors for sales orders. These extractors pull from VBAK/VBAP/VBEP and store snapshots in info cubes.

Custom Z tables are justified only if:

  • You need offline reconciliation snapshots.
  • You need to decouple reporting from live transactional load.
  • You need to integrate with non‚ÄëSAP reporting tools without BW.

entry.title: Re: Create Billing for Service ID
entry.content:
Why you see ‚ÄúMaterial as Service‚Äù instead of service ID is because, in standard SAP, the billing item is determined by the material assigned in the DIP profile. The DIP profile controls how service order actuals (activities, confirmations, costs) are summarized and transferred into billing/quotation. By default, SAP requires a material master to represent the billed item (e.g., ‚ÄúService Material‚Äù), because billing documents in SD are material‚Äëdriven. That‚Äôs why your Service ID or activity number is not appearing ‚Äî the DIP profile is mapping it to the generic material.

If you want the Service ID (activity number) from the service order to appear in billing/quotation, do the following:

  • In the Field Selection / Source Fields, include the Activity Number / Service ID as a field to be transferred. In the Material Determination, instead of mapping to a fixed ‚ÄúService Material,‚Äù configure the profile to use the Service ID field as the material number. This requires that your Service IDs are created as materials in MM (or at least have material master records), because SD billing always expects a material.
  • In the ‚ÄúSource‚Äù column of the DIP profile, select Activity Number (Service ID). In the ‚ÄúSet Name‚Äù column, ensure it is mapped to Material. This way, the system will take the Service ID from the order and pass it as the material in billing.
  • The same DIP profile is used for resource‚Äërelated quotations. Once the Service ID is mapped correctly in the DIP profile, quotations will also show the Service ID instead of the generic service material.

entry.title: Authorization setup for SAC Import Model from S4 ABAP CDS Views
entry.content:
Purpose of this document

The purpose of this blog is to explain how to implement data-level authorization in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories when:

  • Data is extracted from SAP S/4HANA CDS Views
  • The connection type is Import Model
  • Authorization must be enforced based on Company Code and Plant

This approach ensures that users can access only the data they are authorized to see, even though the data is physically stored in SAC.

 

Business Use Case

In many finance and controlling scenarios:

  • A single SAC Story is shared across multiple business users
  • Users belong to different Company Codes and Plant
  • Data is periodically imported from SAP S/4HANA into SAC

Since Import Models store data in SAC, runtime authorisation from S/4HANA (CDS DCLs) is not applied. Therefore, authorization must be designed and enforced within SAC.

 

Authorization Concept for Import Models

When working with SAC Import Models, authorization is handled as follows:

Layer

Responsibility

SAP S/4HANA CDS

Defines which data is extracted

SAC Model

Enforces row-level data authorization

SAC Story

Automatically respects model-level security

Key points to note:
  • CDS DCLs are evaluated only at data extraction time
  • SAC Data Access Control (DAC) governs user visibility
  • Story designers do not need to manage authorization logic
Example Used in This Blog

The same example is used consistently throughout the blog.

Attribute

Value

Authorization Dimensions

Company Code, Plant

Sample Company Code

0100

Sample Plant

RA01, RA02, ‚Ä¶

SAC Connection Type

Import

Source System

SAP S/4HANA CDS View

 

Step-by-Step Authorization Setup

Step 1: Prepare CDS View in SAP S/4HANA

Ensure that the CDS View contains the fields required for authorization, i.e., Company Code and Plant.

Example CDS Used:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZCDEMO002V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Demo Authorization Consumption VIew'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Analytics.query: true
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
define view ZC_DEMO_AUTH_2
  as select from ZI_DEMO_AUTH_1
{
  PurchaseOrder,
  PurchaseOrderItem,
  PurchaseOrderCategory,
  CompanyCode, // Authorization field
  Plant,       // Authorization Field
  @Semantics.currencyCode: true
  DocumentCurrency,
  @DefaultAggregation: #SUM
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'DocumentCurrency'
  PurOrderNetAmount
}

Important notes:

  • Authorization-relevant fields must be part of the CDS output
  • CDS DCLs are not used for runtime authorization in SAC Import Models

 

Step 2: Create Import Model in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to Connections in SAC.
  • Create an SAP S/4HANA Import Connection.
  • Import the CDS View as a Model.

  • At this stage, the data is physically stored in SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Step 3: Enable Data Access Control (DAC)

  • Open the imported Model
  • Navigate to Settings
  • Navigate to Model Preferences
  • Enable Data Access Control

  • This step activates row-level authorization for the model.

 

Step 4: Mark Authorization-Relevant Dimensions

  • Enable data access control for the required dimensions.
  • Select CompanyCode, and Plant.

  • These dimensions are now evaluated during data access.

 

Step 5: Create Data Access Roles

  • Navigate to Security ‚Üí Data Access
  • Create a new Data Access Role

  • Provide Role information, Role template, and review before creating. Template helps to create roles fast for general sections like BI Admin or Planner. In this we will choose template as ‚ÄòBlank‚Äô.

  • After role is created, we will move to ‚ÄòSelect Model‚Äô, choose your import model.

  • Select dimensions required for authorizations and provide values for each.

 

Step 6: Assign Data Access Role to Users

  • Navigate to Security ‚Üí Roles
  • Select the relevant user
  • Assign Business Role ‚Äì SAC_ROLE_DEMO_001 to users for Row-level authorization.
  • The user now inherits Company Code and Plant restrictions.

 

Step 7: Validate Authorization in SAC Story

  • Create or open a Story based on the model.
  • Add a table or chart in story for validation.
  • Include Company Code and Plant as dimensions.
  • Authorization is automatically enforced at runtime.

 

Results

After completing the setup:

  • Data visibility is restricted at row level.
  • A single Story can be reused for multiple user groups.
  • No duplication of Stories or Models is required.
  • Authorization is centrally managed in SAC.
  • Import performance remains unchanged.

 

Best Practices

  • Enable Data Access Control immediately after model creation.
  • Use consistent authorization dimensions across models.
  • Follow clear and business-aligned naming conventions for roles.
  • Do not rely on CDS DCLs for Import Model security.
  • Always validate authorization using multiple test users.

 

Conclusion

When working with SAP Analytics Cloud Import Models based on SAP S/4HANA CDS Views, authorization must be implemented within SAC.

By using:

  • Data Access Control
  • Authorization-enabled dimensions
  • Data Access Roles

you can achieve secure, scalable, and reusable Story-level authorization based on Company Code and Plant fully aligned with standard SAP practices.

entry.title: Re: Fill automatically the purchase org and group field in freight order
entry.content: Dear Sumit, Thank you for your feedback, I am also adding here the feedback from Question: Purchasing organization & Purchasing group determination in Freight order https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/purchasing-organization-amp-purchasing-group-determination-in-freight-order/qaq-p/14038948#M203319. -> Currently, there is no option to directly determine the purchasing organization and purchasing group in a Freight order based on certain conditions. I recommend you to consider implementing API for Freight Order (A2X) to update the Purchasing organization and Purchasing group. As soon the Freight order is created, based on Freight order event, you can trigger the API to update the Purchasing organization and Purchasing group.

entry.title: Which SAP IAS tenant should be used for SAP BTP when configuring Joule in S/4HANA Cloud Public?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently working on the configuration of Joule for a project running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and we have an architecture-related question regarding Identity Authentication Service (IAS).

In our landscape, we have:

  • One IAS Test tenant

  • One IAS Productive tenant

As part of the Joule setup, we also have an SAP BTP tenant included in the project.

Our question is:

Which IAS tenant should be connected to the SAP BTP tenant when implementing Joule?

  • Should SAP BTP be trusted with the IAS Test tenant, or

  • Is it considered best practice to connect SAP BTP directly to the IAS Productive tenant?

Additionally, we would like to understand:

  • What is the recommended SAP best practice for this scenario?

  • Is there a typical approach during implementation phases (test vs. productive)?

  • Are there any considerations specific to S/4HANA Cloud Public + Joule that we should be aware of?

Any guidance, official documentation references, or real-project experience would be greatly appreciated.
We are especially interested in SAP-recommended architectures or official guidance for S/4HANA Cloud Public projects.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Oscar

entry.title: Licnese Service not generating HK on AWS EC2 win2022 , SBO 10.0 SP2511 , mssql 2019

Environment details:

  • SAP Business One: 10.0 SP 2511

  • Database: MS SQL Server 2019

  • OS: Windows Server 2022

  • Infrastructure: AWS EC2

The License Service starts successfully, but no HK is generated, preventing license assignment.

Has anyone encountered this issue on AWS EC2 / virtualized environments, especially with Windows Server 2022?
Are there specific prerequisites, patches, or AWS-related configurations required for HK generation?

Any insights or guidance would be appreciated.

entry.title: Advanced Returns (RMA) Across Two Plants / Two Company Codes
entry.content:
Hi SAP experts,

I‚Äôm looking for insights from anyone who has already implemented the Advanced Returns (RMA) process across two plants belonging to two different company codes.

Context: We need to manage customer returns (RMA) in the following scenario :

  • The customer returns the material to Plant A (Company Code A).

  • If the material cannot be repaired in Plant A, we need to transfer it to Plant B (Company Code B).

  • Plant B performs the repair and then ships the repaired material directly back to the customer.

We would like to know :

  • Is this cross‚Äëcompany, cross‚Äëplant RMA scenario supported in Advanced Returns Management ?

  • What configuration steps or prerequisites are required to make this work ?

  • Do you have any documentation, best practices, or experience to share ?

Thank you in advance for your help and ideas !

entry.title: Re: An End-to-End Hands-On Tutorial for Clean Core RAP Development
entry.content:
Thank you for sharing!

I agree this is a well-structured and probably most reasonable content on the subject we've seen lately. Just some feedback.

1. I'm confused what this has to do with "Clean Core". This is all completely custom development. It doesn't touch the "core", nothing is being or will be extended here. It's technically not wrong, but one could simply remove any clean core mentioning from the post and it would not change any meaning. 

2. I wish SAP would finally get their stuff together on the educational content and put some strategy around it, once and for all. There is a separate website developers.sap.com, which is supposed to contain the actual tutorials. The tutorials there always had a problem that they give you the steps but don't explain why the steps are needed. Which this blog post provides. Why can't the two be finally combined? Then we could finally have true tutorials, with all the tutorial features (such as tracking progress, accomplishments, and links to other content) and the explanation like in this post?

I invite everyone at SAP to read this post, annually. It was written in 2022 but remains valid in what is almost 2026.

entry.title: Re: Extract Document details using Document Information Extraction service with ABAP
entry.content:
Commenting for other people's future benefit

This is a great blog. Myself and couple of colleagues implemented this for a customer.
The biggest pain point for us was to Call the API URL directly.

The below method call did not allow us to get the response back in case of premium BTP version.

cl_http_client=>create_by_url

So we created another RFC destination for the API URL (Example below) without any authentication

aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com

And called this URL in the code with oauth authorization dynamically in code.
It worked like magic.

entry.title: How can we avoid AI slop posts on SCN?
entry.content:
I don't want to see any AI "assisted" (= copy-pasted from ChatGPT) posts. I'm sure I'm not alone in this, people are getting fed up and justly so. Just one random example.

Adding "Gen AI assisted tag" is helpful but doesn't help to avoid the content. Ironically, tag is at the bottom, so you only see it after scrolling through the post.

Is there a way to mute or block the tag?

If not the tag, is it possible to mute or block specific accounts?

entry.title: Re: Timestamp Conversion for Different User Time Zones in ABAP
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing!

It's not clear why the random class cl_kf_helper was chosen, but that's the usual result of letting ChatGPT & Co do ABAP.

Readers, please take a look at many date/time conversion examples from SAP. Don't create unnecessary dependencies on random classes.

entry.title: Re: SAP Office Tables and Workflow Items
entry.content: Workflow inbox items are mainly stored in workflow tables, not classic SAPoffice tables. Key tables include SWWWIHEAD (work item header), SWWUSERWI (user assignments), SWWLOGHIST (history), and SWW_CONT / SWW_CONTOB (container data). For cleanup and size control, SAP‚Äërecommended programs are RSWWWIDE (delete completed work items) and transaction SWWL for workflow administration. SAPoffice tables like SOOD, SOC3, SOFFCONT1 are cleaned using RSBCS_REORG, but workflow data itself is not fully removed by SAPoffice reorg programs.

entry.title: Subcontracting PO scenario with External Manufacturer and multiple company codes involved
entry.content:
Hello All,
Good afternoon
Hope ur doing good
I have one question..
Scenario :
Plant X in company code A is subcontracting its prod to external manufacturer (EM).
Some of the domestic vendors with in US who were shipping Raw materials to plant X will ship same Raws to EM ..
This EM is defined as vendor in SAP .
For international imports the process is go via one of the logistic distribution center of the company .. lets say plant code is B in company code B.. is the logistics center .. How will the EM get the international imports of Raw materials via this logistics center(DC) which is in CC B ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Re: changing the stats_change_threshold value from the de...
entry.content: There is no strict rule of thumb to change stats_change_threshold from the default 50%. SAP generally recommends keeping it unchanged unless there is a proven performance issue. If statistics are too old for very large or frequently changing tables, you can temporarily lower the threshold (for example to 25%) or collect statistics explicitly for specific tables using BRCONNECT or DB20. Any change should be carefully evaluated, as lowering the threshold increases runtime and may impact system performance.

entry.title: Re: Attachment for a Purchase Order !
entry.content:
Create Attachment uploads the document into SAP (stored in SAPoffice tables like SOFFCONT1, unless a Content Server is configured).
Create External Document (URL) only stores a link, not the file itself.

SAP does not recommend storing large documents in the OLTP database; instead, use a Content Server configured via OAC0/OAC3.

For programmatic attachments to a PO, there is no direct PO BAPI. Attachments are handled via GOS, typically using SO_OBJECT_INSERT_API1, or via DMS with BAPI_DOCUMENT_CREATE2, then linking the document to the PO.

entry.title: Re: In rz20 showing red
entry.content:
The alert turns red because a segment has exceeded the configured extent threshold. In your case it‚Äôs a LOB segment (SOFFCONT1).
For LOB segments, online reorg is limited; the usual approach is to move/rebuild the LOB (e.g. ALTER TABLE ‚Ä¶ MOVE LOB ‚Ä¶) or reorganize via SAP‚Äërecommended tools during downtime. Also review and adjust the RZ20 threshold if it‚Äôs too low.

entry.title: Re: dump in Segment builder (urgent)
entry.content: Solution: This dump is caused by duplicate keys during member intersection in CRM Segment Builder. The issue is resolved by implementing SAP Note 1061302, which fixes the duplicate handling in FM CRM_MKTTG_MEMBER_TAB_INTERSECT. After applying the note, the profile set can be created without dumps.

entry.title: Re: Error reorg table with brspace
entry.content:
This error is usually not caused by BRSPACE options. In this case it was due to an Oracle patch not being linked correctly.

Fix:

  1. Stop SAP, database, and listener

  2. Log in as ora<SID>

  3. Run relink all

  4. Start SAP again

After relinking, the online reorg with BRSPACE worked fine. Also make sure the required SAP bundle patches and Oracle scripts (catalog.sql / catproc.sql) are correctly applied.

entry.title: Re: MESSAGE_TYPE_X dump in RSBCS_REORG (SAPLSZA0 READ_DB_ADDRESS)
entry.content: Thanks for the input. Running Z_OSSNOTE_436119 and checking ADCP for blank address numbers resolved the MESSAGE_TYPE_X dump in RSBCS_REORG. Appreciate the help.

entry.title: Re: GOS 'Create Attachment' - Can we archive it to DMS?
entry.content:
In standard SAP, GOS ‚ÄúCreate Attachment‚Äù cannot be routed to DMS or a Content Server.
Attachments created via GOS are always stored in the SAP database tables (SOFFCONT1 / SOC3).

If you want documents to be stored outside the DB:

  • Use ‚ÄúStore Business Document‚Äù with Content Server configuration, or

  • Disable Create Attachment (as you already did), or

  • Implement a custom ABAP solution (enhancing GOS classes) to copy/store documents in DMS.

There is no standard configuration to redirect GOS Create Attachment to DMS.

Therefore, the recommended and supported approach is to use Store Business Document or external archiving.

entry.title: Re: GOS attachment and KPRO
entry.content: GOS attachments are handled via SAPoffice/BDS and can be routed through KPro by configuring a Content Repository (OAC0). Once KPro is active and linked to the business object, attachments can be stored on an external content server instead of SOFFCONT1/SOC3.

entry.title: Re: How to Link Invoices for Journal Vouchers
entry.content: Solution: In SAP Business One, invoice amounts written off via Journal Entries should be cleared using Business Partner Internal Reconciliation. This properly links the invoice and JE, closes the invoice, and also updates INV6, ensuring aging and custom queries show correct outstanding balances.

entry.title: Re: External Storage for Business documents - Managing se...
entry.content:
When using External Storage / Content Server, failures during outages are not always visible to end users, especially for GOS attachments and background processes. Typically, issues can be traced via:

  • SLG1 (Object: BC_KPRO, ARCHIVELINK) for KPro/ArchiveLink errors

  • SOST / SOSTMON for outbound document failures (payment advices, outputs)

  • SM21 / ST22 for short dumps and system log entries

  • CCMS (RZ20) for Content Server availability monitoring

Failed attachments are usually not automatically retried. A common practice is to:

  • Implement custom logging or user exit checks for attachment creation

  • Monitor Content Server availability proactively and block attachment actions during outages

  • Provide a manual re‚Äëattach/reprocess procedure for users once the server is back online

SAP does not provide a central retry queue for all business documents, so operational monitoring and user communication are key.

entry.title: Re: Remote client copy errors
entry.content:
These errors during remote client copy usually point to RFC/network interruptions or work process terminations, not table inconsistencies. The SM21 logs clearly show repeated ‚ÄúConnection lost‚Äù messages, which explains the read/conversion and program cancel errors.

Recommended actions:

  • Ensure stable network connectivity between PRD and QAS during the copy window.

  • Increase rdisp/max_wprun_time and verify enough dialog/background WPs.

  • Run Remote RFC Comparison in SCC8 before retrying.

  • If the client is large, prefer client export/import instead of remote copy.

Copying tables manually via transport is not recommended and may cause inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Performance Issues with RSBCS_REORG
entry.content:
Hi Manik,

Long runtime of RSBCS_REORG is a known issue. Please check SAP Note 1615366 ‚Äì ‚ÄúRSBCS_REORG: Long runtime (SOMG)‚Äù.

In many systems, table SOMG contains entries with initial values in DOCTP, DOCYR, and DOCNO, which causes unnecessary database reads and leads to very long runtimes.

Recommended actions:

  • Implement SAP Note 1615366 via SNOTE, or

  • Apply the relevant Support Package that contains the correction.

  • After implementation, performance of RSBCS_REORG improves significantly.

Best regards.

entry.title: Re: Problem with slow Unicode export
entry.content: The long Unicode export runtime is mainly due to the very large SOFFCONT1 table, which stores attachments as binary data. Deleting only a small percentage of entries usually does not significantly reduce export time. SAP generally recommends archiving or moving attachments to an external content server (ArchiveLink/KPro) before Unicode export, or getting SAP support guidance for table‚Äëspecific export optimization. In such cases, involving SAP (as you did) is the correct approach, since SOFFCONT1 handling during Unicode conversion is system‚Äë and DB‚Äëspecific.

entry.title: Re: unicode migration via socket
entry.content: We are using MigMon version <x.x> and R3load patch <yy>. Network is stable and socket prerequisites are met. Can you confirm which MigMon patch fixes the BUSY issue, or share the SAP Note number?

entry.title: Re: Where is the Offline form stored after its emailed ou...
entry.content: If ArchiveLink or external storage is not used, the submitted offline Adobe form is stored internally in SAP Office tables, mainly SOFFCONT1 (content) and related tables. The inbound email and processing details can be checked in SOST, while spool-related output (if generated) can be seen in SP01. Retrieval is possible but not user‚Äëfriendly without ArchiveLink; refer to SAP Note 904711 for storage and handling details.

entry.title: Re: Problem in SOST
entry.content: The main reason for slow SOST startup is usually large SAPoffice tables (SOFFCONT1, SOC3, ADRVP). Regular SAPoffice reorganization (e.g. RSBCS_REORG / SARA ‚Äì SAP_BCS) should be scheduled by Basis. After cleanup, SOST performance improves significantly.

entry.title: Re: SAP Personas - table view on mobile
entry.content:
Unfortunately, increasing the number of rows in SAP GUI for HTML is not possible, because this is controlled by backend functionality. In general, the maxRows property of the table / grid can only be used to decrease the number of visible rows. If this is increased, it will be ignored, and the backend screen definition will determine how many rows are shown.

Different rules apply when rendering the table via Slipstream Engine. The maxRows property's effect is described in note 2557076. However, increasing the number of rows should only be used with display-only tables, as with editable tables this is likely to cause problems and in general, it doesn't seem to work properly. There are technical reasons why this is so.
